header.title: Black Magic Spells
authors: Compiled from various grimoires and occult traditions

central_thesis: This book serves as a practical manual for individuals seriously interested in black magic, offering detailed instructions for evoking and commanding spirits, performing curses, and executing various operative magical rites for personal gain, protection, or harm, with an explicit emphasis on strict adherence to instructions and precautions due to inherent dangers.

structure_content.summary: Explores the Black Mass as a magical ceremony, parodying Catholic rites for mocking God and worshipping the Devil. It details historical accounts, various blasphemous elements, and practices such as human sacrifice, obscenity, and the use of unconventional hosts and chalices.

Describes the three ascending grades of contemporary witchcraft initiation, outlining rituals involving nudity, blindfolding, oaths of secrecy, the 'five-fold kiss,' scourging, and the presentation of 'working tools of the Art' with explanations of their uses.
Presents the traditional nine orders of angels, categorized into three hierarchies, and contextualizes devils as fallen angels who retain their original celestial ranks.

Details a hierarchical classification of prominent devils (e.g., Beelzebub, Lucifer, Leviathan, Asmodeus, Balberith, Astaroth) within their original angelic choirs (Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones, Powers, Dominions, Principalities, Archangels, Angels), attributing specific temptations and roles to each.

structure_content.chapter_title: Devils and the Seven Deadly Sins
structure_content.summary: Associates key devils (Lucifer, Mammon, Asmodeus, Satan, Beelzebub, Leviathan, Belphegor) with their corresponding Seven Deadly Sins (Pride, Avarice, Lechery, Anger, Gluttony, Envy, Sloth), illustrating their primary areas of temptation.

Explains the occult significance of divine and demonic names as conduits of power, used in incantations and magic circle construction to evoke spirits and compel obedience. A comprehensive list of such names is provided.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conjuring Spirits / The Magick Instruments required for conjuring Spirits
structure_content.summary: Describes essential magical instruments: the Magick Wand (including Athame and Necromancy wand), Magick Sword, and Magick Robes. Instructions for their preparation, inscription, consecration, and symbolic significance are detailed.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Magick Circle, and the Composition thereof
structure_content.summary: Provides guidance on constructing and preparing the magic circle, emphasizing its protective function and role in spirit confirmation. It outlines considerations for timing, planetary alignments, and the inscription of divine names, spirit offices, characters, pentacles, and seals within the circle.

Presents a step-by-step process for evoking evil spirits, including pre-evocation research (spirit nature, planetary associations), selection of a suitable location and time, necessary provisions (lights, perfumes, holy items), and the conjuration sequence, which may involve repeated commands, abjurations, and threats.

Offers specific conjuration texts for various spirits, including a general conjuration utilizing a multitude of divine and powerful names (e.g., BARALAMENSIS, ADONAI, TETRAGRAMMATON) to compel appearance and obedience. A 'Constraint' section includes more forceful names and curses for recalcitrant entities.
A ritualistic address to be recited upon the spirit's appearance, binding it to remain within the triangle and fulfill the magician's demands before receiving license to depart.
Lists Cassiel's name in the table of contents as a specific spirit for conjuration.
Provides a specific conjuration text to invoke Lucifer, listing numerous names (e.g., Ouyar, Chameron, Aliseon) to call him forth.
Details a specific conjuration text for Astaroth, including a series of names (e.g., Ador, Cameso, Valluerituf Mareso) to summon this entity.
Presents a specific conjuration text for Beelzebub, featuring various names (e.g., Madilont, Solymo, Saroy) to invoke him.

Outlines the procedure for dismissing a spirit after its tasks are completed, emphasizing polite words and commands for peaceful departure, with provisions for forceful expulsion if the spirit is obstinate.

Describes the nature and conditions of a Devil's Pact, including a historical example (Pignerole, 1676) listing 28 demands from the Devil (e.g., wealth, protection, influence, knowledge) in exchange for the renunciation of God and submission of body and soul.

Defines necromancy as divination through communication with the dead, detailing its historical context (e.g., John Dee, Edward Kelley) and two main branches (ghosts, corpses). It highlights the dangers, necessary precautions, and specific ritual components like burnt offerings, blood, planetary study, and magic circles.

structure_content.chapter_title: Summoning a Spirit from a Tomb
structure_content.summary: Presents a specialized churchyard necromancy technique for summoning a spirit from its resting place, including specific incantations ('Ego sum te peto et uidere queo!') and commands for dismissal ('Return to the Kingdom of the Chosen!').

Discusses H.P. Lovecraft's fictional grimoire, its supposed origins, and warns of the psychological dangers and authenticity of its magic, stating 'THIS IS NOT A FARCE!!!' and guaranteeing its legitimacy from a former occult follower's perspective. It includes several 'Spells from the Necronomicon'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Spells from the Necronomicon / The Conjuration "The Binding of the Evil Sorcerers"
structure_content.summary: An ancient-sounding incantation to bind evil sorcerers, with a critical note that one verse has been omitted for the practitioner's safety, rendering it ineffective if tried as written.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Conjuration "XILQA XILQA BESA BESA" or "A Most Excellent Charm Against the Hordes of Demons" etc.
structure_content.summary: A complete incantation designed to banish wickedness and demons, compelling them to depart from the body and be held back by powerful deities (Shamash, Enki, Marduk, God of Fire).
Another incantation for binding sorcerers, also with a verse intentionally omitted for the safety of the practitioner, ensuring it will not work as listed.

structure_content.chapter_title: "The Conjuration of the Mountains of MASHU"
structure_content.summary: A complete incantation invoking the 'mountain' to overpower, hold back, conquer, frighten, shake, check, subject, cover, and fall upon a target, effectively binding and controlling it.

Introduces magical seals from 'Dr. Johannes Faust's "Miracle and Wonder Book"' for various purposes such as protection, invisibility, compelling infernal spirits, and locating treasure. Provides specific instructions for their engraving, timing, and use.

Explains the system of magic from 'The Book of the Sacred Magic of Abra-Melin the Mage,' focusing on the concept of 'magic squares' for generating 'Hatred and Enmity, Discords, Quarrels, Contentions, Combats, Battles, Loss, and Damage.' Instructions for their use by evoking Angels and Evil Spirits (specifically BEELZEBUB) are provided.

structure_content.chapter_title: Demons of the Goetia, their Seals and Abilities (Part 1)
structure_content.summary: Catalogs numerous Goetic demons (e.g., Bael, Agares, Marbas, Amon, Paimon, Asmoday, Belial), presenting their seals and detailing their specific forms, offices, and abilities, which range from teaching arts and sciences to causing love, hatred, destruction, or revealing hidden things.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pictures of the Deamons from the Goetia
structure_content.summary: Presents illustrations of several prominent Goetic demons (e.g., Agares, Amon, Barbatos, Buer, Eligos, Ipos, Naberius, Astaroth, Foras, Furfur, Asmoday, Amdusias, Andras, Aim, Haures, Balam, Alloces) sourced from Collin de Plancy's 'Dictionnaire Infernal (1863).'
A healing spell where the word 'ABRACADABRA' is written on parchment and placed around the neck of a sick individual to make a fever disappear as the word itself gradually vanishes.
A curse or warning spell utilizing a black candle and a chant ('Blood turn black and flesh turn blue...') to inflict negative physical and spiritual effects on an enemy.
A spell designed to cause a romantic breakup, using magazine pictures of a boy and girl that are first laid together, then separated, symbolizing the dissolution of the relationship.

structure_content.chapter_title: Spells, Rituals and Black Magick / Binding-Spell
structure_content.summary: A binding spell intended to halt an individual's negative actions, involving a jar, a candle representing the target, moist earth, and sealing the jar with wax, then placing it in a cold, undisturbed location.
A comprehensive, encyclopedic list of various divination methods, ranging from Aeromancy (divining by air) to Tyromancy (by coagulation of cheese), highlighting the breadth of esoteric practices.

A collection of practical black magic spells for diverse purposes, including banishing troublesome persons, inflicting pain, causing bad luck, and manipulating relationships. Detailed instructions for each spell are provided, often involving specific ingredients and chants.

A collection of spells aimed at altering physical appearance, including enhancing beauty, changing specific body features (e.g., hands, hips, breasts), curing ailments (acne), and hair growth/loss. The section also includes spells for increasing or decreasing popularity (glamour).
Spells designed to influence body weight, including potions to cause rapid weight gain or loss, utilizing various ingredients, chants, and specific preparation methods.
A meditation spell to strengthen willpower for various situations, involving light blue, white, or purple candles, incense, and a specific chant to guide oneself towards goals and overcome conflicts.
Spells focused on manipulating an individual's attractiveness and popularity, using colored chalk to symbolically enhance or diminish a person's 'glamour' by drawing their image and chanting.
Spells to either create or prevent hair growth, or cause hair loss, through potions and rituals involving candles, dirt, clay, and water, with warnings about potential miscast consequences.

Spells to enhance physical attributes such as strength, agility, and sturdiness, using symbolic ingredients and actions like dirt in a pentagon, orange rind, or ashes from an oak stick, combined with specific chants.

structure_content.chapter_title: Considerations and Conjurations for every Day in the Week
structure_content.summary: Provides detailed 'Considerations' (angels, planetary rulers, winds, perfumes) and 'Conjurations' for each day of the week (Sunday through Saturday). Each daily section outlines specific angels to invoke, divine names, and the familiar forms in which spirits of that day may appear, along with their respective natures and offices (e.g., procuring gold, causing war, revealing secrets).

key_concepts.definition: The selfish perversion of magical arts to destroy others, or for personal gain; the conscious use of black magic rituals for the exercise of evil. Black magicians often make pacts with the Devil and invoke diabolic powers.

A consecrated space, varied in form according to the spirits called, used for defense of the master and confirmation of the spirit during conjurations. It typically contains divine names, spirit offices, characters, pentacles, and seals.

A ritualistic command or invocation, often repeated multiple times and with increasing force (abjurations, contumelies, curses), to compel a spirit or demon to appear and obey the magician's will, using powerful divine or demonic names.
The act of calling forth a spirit from its dwelling place into manifest appearance, requiring prior knowledge of its nature, planetary agreements, and appropriate timing and location.

Significant divine or demonic names that transmit and contain the power of the associated entity. Chanting these names repeatedly is believed to activate the entity's power and bring the magician into a state of frenzy to compel the spirit.
A black-hilted knife, endowed with magical properties, primarily used for drawing magic circles and directing energy in rituals. Its design is often derived from grimoires like 'The Key of Solomon'.

A formal agreement wherein an individual offers their soul, body, and renounces divine allegiance in exchange for specific material benefits, power, or services from the Devil or demons, as exemplified by the Pignerole pact of 1676.

The ancient art of communicating with the dead for divination, divided into divination by ghosts and divination from corpses. It is considered dangerous, requiring pacts with the Devil and elaborate precautions against vengeful 'astral corpses'.

A system of magic from 'The Book of the Sacred Magic of Abra-Melin the Mage,' based on controlling spirits through the 'knowledge and conversation' of the Holy Guardian Angel. It primarily employs 'magic squares' â€“ arrangements of letters designed to achieve specific wishes, often with warnings of danger without proper preparation.

A system of ceremonial magic, often derived from 'The Lesser Key of Solomon,' focused on the evocation and command of seventy-two specific demons (e.g., Bael, Agares, Lucifer), each with their own seals, forms, and offices, to perform various tasks for the magician.

A powerful folk magic mixture, particularly from African-American hoodoo tradition, typically made from graveyard dirt, cat ashes, sulphur, red pepper, mullein leaves, snake skin, spider webs, and crushed snail shells, used to drive people away, harm them, make them sick, or for coercive love spells.

Magical operations designed to influence a person's attractiveness or popularity by manipulating their 'glamour,' the power to attract attention through physical appearance. These spells can either enhance or diminish a target's appeal.
In Abramelin magic, a being considered the magician's true self, whose 'knowledge and conversation' must be acquired before one can safely control spirits of the material world.
A symbol of authority and supreme power in witchcraft, typically made of hazel (or graveyard tree for necromancy), inscribed with specific characters and consecrated for ritual use.
An instrument for drawing magic circles and controlling spirits, often engraved with magical symbols and characters.

practical_system.description: The book presents a practical, operative magical system rooted in grimoire and folk traditions. It primarily involves the evocation and conjuration of spirits (angels, devils, deceased) to manifest desired outcomes, ranging from material acquisition and interpersonal influence to healing, protective measures, offensive curses, and physical transformations. The system's efficacy hinges on meticulous adherence to instructions, precise timing (often linked to planetary hours and days), the use of specially prepared ritual tools, and the potent utterance of divine, angelic, or demonic names. Additionally, it incorporates various folk-magic type spells that rely on specific ingredients, sympathetic magic, and focused visualization.

Lights (candles, black, red, yellow, orange, white, purple, various sizes)

Abramelin Magic (using magic squares for influence and harm)
Pact with the Devil (formal agreements for power and benefits)
Binding Spells (e.g., Binding by Fear Ritual)

relevant_quotes.text: This book is for those, who are seriously interested in black magic. People with prejudices and the mob should stay away from here: they would only toddle in darkness and be highly indignant. The described black magic rituals are not without danger and are consequently unsuitable for people who are not mentally in good constitution. Take heed to follow all instructions the way they are described. Without the necessary precautions every ritual will turn to your disadvantage, confusion and total destruction. On the contrary, by following the instructions with precision, you will achieve a complete success in all your enterprises.

Black magic is the selfish perversion of magical arts to destroy others, or for personal gain. The conscious use of black magic rituals for the exercise of evil. The black magician is a person who wants power for himself.
If you would have any promise confirmed upon oath, stretch the sword out of the circle, and swear the Spirit by laying his hand upon the sword.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book compiles a broad spectrum of black magic and operative occult practices, providing a direct glimpse into grimoire traditions and folk magic. Its value lies in its explicit instructions for various magical operations, ranging from demon evocation and necromancy to personal influence and counter-magical acts. The text is relevant for understanding historical magical beliefs, the mechanics of operative magic, and the cultural perception of 'black arts.' The self-contradictory warnings and endorsements, particularly regarding the 'Necronomicon,' reflect a characteristic blend of caution, theatricality, and alleged authenticity often found in occult literature.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is clearly stated as 'those, who are seriously interested in black magic,' with explicit warnings against 'people with prejudices and the mob' or those 'not mentally in good constitution.' This indicates a readership of serious, committed, and perhaps experienced practitioners of operative magic, demonology, or necromancy. It also caters to those studying the historical and practical aspects of ceremonial magic and witchcraft, who are prepared to engage with ethically challenging and potentially dangerous practices described in the text.
